name: heat and power co-generation, hard coal | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/13399/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity and district heat in an average combined heat and power hard coal power plant in Austria in 2012. The exchanges are valid for 1MJ of hard coal burned. "Hard coal" includes anthracite, coking coal and other bituminous coal according to the definition of the IEA electricity information 2014.;All exchanges in this dataset except for emissions of SO2, NOx and particles are production-weighted averages of the figures in the datasets in ecoinvent version two, which are valid for the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US. The exception values are production-weighted averages of version 2 countries and the new countries in version 3 (AU, CA, CL, ID, IN, KR, MX, MY, PE, RU, TH, TR, TW, TZ, UA, ZA){{children_only}};Comments on the inventory data of emissions: ;- For the assessment of main characteristics (sulphur and ash content of coal, efficiency of the plant) and CO2 a bottom-up approach has been used. It consists in the collection of information about single plants.;- The size distribution of particle emissions has been derived from German data. ; - Halogene emissions have been estimated on the basis of the content of the species in the country-specific coal input mix, assuming average retention rates. ;- For CO and particle emissions average values for the former UCTE are included (Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity).   ; - The country specific emission depend on the share of DeNOx. ; - Emissions of trace elements were calculated by means of a formula (CORINAIR) using the ash content in the country-specific coal input mix and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants, taking into account the share of DeSOx installed. ; - Emission of uranium and thorium radioactive isotopes were assumed proportional to the corresponding element emitted with particles; the other non-gaseous radioactive isotopes of the uranium and thorium decay chain were assumed proportional to the emitted U-238 or Th-232.  ;- The emission of gaseous radon and K-40 are taken from the literature.;IEA. 2014. Electricity Information 2014. ISBN 978-92-64-21692-1. International Energy Agency (IEA), Paris Cedex (FR);European Environment Agency (1991) CORINAIR Inventory; VOC"s Default Emission Factors;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From the constructed hard coal power plant ready to produce electricity. 
From reception of hard coal and operating materials at power plant gate. Functional unit is the combustion of 1MJ of hard coal.

This activity ends with heat and electricity generated in a CHP power plant.
This dataset includes: 
 - all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants. 
 - Use of fuel oil for startup
 - Particle removal (dedusting of the flue gas)

  - Desulfurisation and denitrification. These processes are described in separate modules; it can be decided by changing the values of NOx and SOx retained whether and how much DeNOx and DeSOx are installed. 
 - Cooling: It is assumed that all plants use wet cooling with a cooling tower. No cooling tower is included in this dataset (will be implemented in future versions)
 - Loss of feed water 


This dataset doesn"t include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets
 - transformation of the electricity produced
 - The disposal of non-recycled ashes is modelled separately.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: POWER PLANT:;Hard coal power plant input is a market mix of 100MWe power plants (representing all power plants with a capacity <250MWe and 7% of the installed capacity) and 500MWe power plants (representing all power plants with a capacity >250MWe and 93% of the installed capacity). The plants are used for middle load with 4000 hours of operation at full capacity per year. The plants are assumed to operate 150000 hours during its lifetime.;Coal power plants are installed with an electrical filter and a flue gas desulfurization (DeSOx). To a large extent a selective catalytic reduction (SCR) takes place and a DeNOx plant is installed additionally. The electrical filter is the most widely used technology in UCTE countries. The system is highly efficient with filtration efficiency up to 99.9%. The electrical filter increases the energy consumption. The downstream flue gas desulfurization (DeSOx) reduces the particles further by 80% to 95%.; - Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Original emission data from 1993 have been updated for the years 2000 (v1.0), and 2004-2005 (v2.0). Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly. 

Most of the exchanges were extrapolated through production-weighted averages of the datasets of the following 14 countries: AT, BE, ES, FR, IT, NL, PT, DE, CZ, HR, PL, SK, CN, US.

exchanges.description: Electricity output per MJ of hard coal burned.

flow.name: Chromium VI
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The cleaning of the steam generators usually leaves residues that are burdened with surfactants and residues that contain metal ions. For the cleaning also mordents are used. The residues from the cooling tower contain organic ingredients (pollen, leaves, etc.) but also corrosion products of the cooling tower, chalk and iron hydroxide from additional water treatment. Per TJin 5 kg of residues from cooling tower are assumed.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Potassium-40
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The water treatment for the wet cooling and for feed water treatment is recorded separately. According to (Euler 1984) the share of river cooled power plants was 58% in 1978. 42% of the power plants were operated with wet cooling. According to (Brune et al. 1984) 33% of hard coal power plants are operated with wet cooling towers in 1980. Since 1978 practically all power plants have been built with wet cooling towers. It is believed that around 50% of river cooled power plants have been shut down or equipped with wet cooling towers. It results an assumed share of river cooled power plants of 25% in the whole UCTE area. 

Further references:
Brune D., Stehfest H. (1984) Folgen eines verstarkten Kohleeinsatzes in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; Teilbericht: Umweltfolgeanalysen für Abwasseremissionen und feste Rückstande aus der Kohlegewinnung und -nutzung. Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe KfK 3526.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The calorific value of the consumed coal in the coal power plant (26.8 MJ/kg) is adapted to the country specific calorific value of the supply mix (23.2 MJ/kg). The calorific value of the consumed coal is derived from power plant operators. The calorific value of the supply mix is obtained from the proportions and different compositions of the different production regions. 

Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Pentane
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Data is out of a bottom-up approach and based on the collection of information about single plants (Maude et al., 1994) with updated information for year 2000 (Jahrbuch 2001). Additionally country specific data is available from coal power plant operators (Tauschitz et al. 1997), (Verbund 2002), (Energie Oberösterreich 1999), (Steweag), (Guttenbrunner et al. 1998). For about 60% of installed capacity in hard coal power plants detailed values for emissions and electricity production are available. 
The filtration efficiency for particles with a high diameter is 100%. For particles <0.2 microm, which also have the highest trace element concentrations, the filtration efficiency is lower. Based on data from (LNRW 1993) 20% of the particles are >10 microm. Here it is assumed that 5% of the particles are >10 microm, 10% of the particles are between 2.5 and 10 microm, and 85% of the particles are <2.5 microm. Beside particles from the chimney further emissions occur through removals from freight cars, conveyor belts to the storage area, storage, inventory reduction, transportation to the silo, cooling tower, streets and chalk storage. In (Hesketh et al. 1983) different retention techniques are distinguished and an additional emission factor of 5kg per TJin is assumed for particles >10 microm.


Further references:
Klatt H.-J., Meller E., Middelschulte A., Milojcic G., Reichel W., Riemer H.-W. (2001) Jahrbuch 2001 der europaischen Energie- und Rohstoffwirtschaft, 108. Jg. Gückauf, Essen.
Tauschitz J., Kager W., Voges W. (1997) Restwarmeauskopplung im Dampfkraftwerk Voitsberg 3 In: VGB KraftwerksTechnik 77 2/97 S. 98-103.
Verbund (2002) Umweltbericht 2001. Österreichische Elektrizitatswirtschafts-Aktiengesellschaft (Verbundgesellschaft). Wien
Energie Oberösterreich AG (1999) Umwelterklarung für den Standort Riedersbach, Riedersbach 1999, http://www.energieag.at/riedersbach/index.html und Informationen über das Kraftwerk Timelkam (www.energieag.at/lambach/kws/timelkam/seite1.html), 8.8.2002
Steweag (2002) http://www.steweag-steg.com/plant/mellach.htm. Steirische Wasserkraft- und Elektrizitats-AG, 9.8.2002.
Guttenbrunner M., Madlsperger G., Pfeffer S., Steiner H. (1998) Umrüstung der Braunhohle-Kraftwerke der Oberösterreichischen Kraftwerke AG auf Steinkohle. In: VGB KraftwerksTechnik 78 6/98 S. 81-86.
LNRW (1993) Reduzierung der durch Kokerein verursachten Umweltbelastung. Landtag Nordrhein-Westfalen, Drucksache 11/5438. Düsseldorf.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Hydrogen fluoride
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Fuel oil is primarily used for starting up the plant. For medium load hard coal power plants typically 450g of fuel oil and 0.5g of diesel per ton of burned hard coal is necessary. This results in 0.73 GJ of fuel oil per TJin.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Thorium-232
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The water for the ash removal is used without treatment. According to (Euler 1984) the share of river cooled power plants was 58% in 1978. 42% of the power plants were operated with wet cooling. According to (Brune et al. 1984) 33% of hard coal power plants are operated with wet cooling towers in 1980. Since 1978 practically all power plants have been built with wet cooling towers. It is believed that around 50% of river cooled power plants have been shut down or equipped with wet cooling towers. It results an assumed share of river cooled power plants of 25% in the whole UCTE area. 

Further references:
Brune D., Stehfest H. (1984) Folgen eines verstarkten Kohleeinsatzes in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; Teilbericht: Umweltfolgeanalysen für Abwasseremissionen und feste Rückstande aus der Kohlegewinnung und -nutzung. Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe KfK 3526.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
Calculated based on literature (Scown, C.D., et al., 2011, Water Footprint of U.S. Trasportation Fuels;Scown, C.D., et al., 2011, Water Footprint of U.S. Trasportation Fuels (SI); Stiegel, 2008, Estimating Freshwater Needs to Meet Future Thermoelectric Generation Requirements; Floerke, M., 2009, Future changes of freshwater needs in the electricity production sector), (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). Water use in this process is modelled based on literature (see references). The process boundaries are given by the boundaries of the power plant. The process ends when the energy (MJ) is produced and ready to be used for electricity production (kWh).
Calculated based on literature data.

Estimation. The amount of retained SOx is gathered from a bottom-up approach and based on the collection of information about single plants (Maude et al., 1994) with updated information for year 2000 (Jahrbuch 2001). Additionally country specific data is available from coal power plant operators (Tauschitz et al. 1997), (Verbund 2002), (Energie Oberösterreich 1999), (Steweag), (Guttenbrunner et al. 1998). For about 60% of installed capacity in hard coal power plants detailed values for emissions and electricity production are available. 

Further references:
Klatt H.-J., Meller E., Middelschulte A., Milojcic G., Reichel W., Riemer H.-W. (2001) Jahrbuch 2001 der europaischen Energie- und Rohstoffwirtschaft, 108. Jg. Gückauf, Essen.
Tauschitz J., Kager W., Voges W. (1997) Restwarmeauskopplung im Dampfkraftwerk Voitsberg 3 In: VGB KraftwerksTechnik 77 2/97 S. 98-103.
Verbund (2002) Umweltbericht 2001. Österreichische Elektrizitatswirtschafts-Aktiengesellschaft (Verbundgesellschaft). Wien
Energie Oberösterreich AG (1999) Umwelterklarung für den Standort Riedersbach, Riedersbach 1999, http://www.energieag.at/riedersbach/index.html und Informationen über das Kraftwerk Timelkam (www.energieag.at/lambach/kws/timelkam/seite1.html), 8.8.2002
Steweag (2002) http://www.steweag-steg.com/plant/mellach.htm. Steirische Wasserkraft- und Elektrizitats-AG, 9.8.2002.
Guttenbrunner M., Madlsperger G., Pfeffer S., Steiner H. (1998) Umrüstung der Braunhohle-Kraftwerke der Oberösterreichischen Kraftwerke AG auf Steinkohle. In: VGB KraftwerksTechnik 78 6/98 S. 81-86.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. At the moment, the hard coal power plant input consists of a market mix of a 100MWe power plant and a 500MWe power plant
. 
For this calculation, 4000 load hours per year are assumed. It is assumed that a total of 150"000h is reached during the lifetime. A capacity of 500MW is taken for the calculation.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Data is out of a bottom-up approach and based on the collection of information about single plants (Maude et al., 1994) with updated information for year 2000 (Jahrbuch 2001). Additionally country specific data is available from coal power plant operators (Tauschitz et al. 1997), (Verbund 2002), (Energie Oberösterreich 1999), (Steweag), (Guttenbrunner et al. 1998). For about 60% of installed capacity in hard coal power plants detailed values for emissions and electricity production are available. 
The filtration efficiency for particles with a high diameter is 100%. For particles <0.2 microm, which also have the highest trace element concentrations, the filtration efficiency is lower. Based on data from (LNRW 1993) 20% of the particles are >10 microm. Here it is assumed that 5% of the particles are >10 microm, 10% of the particles are between 2.5 and 10 microm, and 85% of the particles are <2.5 microm. Beside particles from the chimney further emissions occur through removals from freight cars, conveyor belts to the storage area, storage, inventory reduction, transportation to the silo, cooling tower, streets and chalk storage. In (Hesketh et al. 1983) different retention techniques are distinguished and an additional emission factor of 5kg per TJin is assumed for particles >10 microm.


Further references:
Klatt H.-J., Meller E., Middelschulte A., Milojcic G., Reichel W., Riemer H.-W. (2001) Jahrbuch 2001 der europaischen Energie- und Rohstoffwirtschaft, 108. Jg. Gückauf, Essen.

flow.name: Boron
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The ash content of hard coal mined in Europe is usually between 10% and 25%. Imported coal has an ash content of mostly less than 10% (Brune et al. 1984) and (Maude et al 1994). Therefore, the weighted ash content of the country is taken into account. Due to the respective retention technology the amount of avoided ash is calculated. 
The ash accrues as bottom ash or fly ash. In case of slag tap firing granules accrue, since the high temperature leads to a vitreous substance. If a fly ash recirculation takes place, the ash accrues completely as granulate, without fly ash recirculation the proportion is 50%. In case of dry firing 15% to 20% of the ash accrue as bottom ash, the rest as fly ash (VGB 1992).
According to data provided by operators and associations a recycling rate of 95% is assumed. Difficulties arise only with ashes from fluidized bed furnaces, which are difficult to handle. In Austria 4’352 kg per TJin of hard coal ash accrues, 217.6 kg of ash per TJin is deposited. This information relates only to the inorganic fraction of the ash. 
It is not clear if the recycled ash is a by-product or waste product. It is not known whether, for example, the cement and concrete industry pays something for the ash or even get something for it.

Further references:
Brune D., Stehfest H. (1984) Folgen eines verstarkten Kohleeinsatzes in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; Teilbericht: Umweltfolgeanalysen für Abwasseremissionen und feste Rückstande aus der Kohlegewinnung und -nutzung. Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe KfK 3526.
VGB und VDEW (1992) Verwertungskonzept für Reststoffe aus Kohlekraftwerken in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. VGB-TW 702, Essen.

Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Dioxins, measured as 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The water treatment for the wet cooling and for feed water treatment is recorded separately. According to (Euler 1984) the share of river cooled power plants was 58% in 1978. 42% of the power plants were operated with wet cooling. According to (Brune et al. 1984) 33% of hard coal power plants are operated with wet cooling towers in 1980. Since 1978 practically all power plants have been built with wet cooling towers. It is believed that around 50% of river cooled power plants have been shut down or equipped with wet cooling towers. It results an assumed share of river cooled power plants of 25% in the whole UCTE area. 

Further references:
Brune D., Stehfest H. (1984) Folgen eines verstarkten Kohleeinsatzes in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; Teilbericht: Umweltfolgeanalysen für Abwasseremissionen und feste Rückstande aus der Kohlegewinnung und -nutzung. Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe KfK 3526.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
